text: Look  at  this.  This  real  asteroid  is  the
size  of  a  building  and  it's  on  a
collision  course  for  Earth.  But  can  you

At  9:00  a.m.  on  February  15th,  2013,
it's  a  normal  morning  in  Chelabinsk,
Russia,  when  suddenly  people  see
something  bright  in  the  sky.  Some  even
feel  the  air  get  hotter.  Above  them,
that  building  sized  rock  hits  our
atmosphere  going  67,000
kilometers  per  hour  and  23  km  up,  it
explodes.  People  come  to  their  windows
to  see  what  happened.  But  90  seconds
later,  the  shock  wave  hits.
Within  4  days,  debris  from  that  blast
circles  our  entire  planet.  And  the
scariest  part  is  no  one  saw  it  coming.
>> Scientists  had  no  idea  this  was  coming.

>> Yes.  Right  now,  we're  at  the  real
Catalina  Sky  Survey  because  they've
invited  us  to  spend  the  night  with  them
while  they  hunt  for  real  asteroids.
Since  the  1990s,  this  place  and  places
like  it  around  the  world  have  scanned
the  sky  while  we're  all  asleep,  hunting
for  dangerous  objects  that  might  hit  us.
Together,  these  groundbased
observatories  have  detected  the  majority
of  the  near-Earth  asteroids  that  we  know
about,  over  39,000
so  far.  We  don't  think  about  it  very
often,  but  our  planet  is  in  a  constant
high  stakes  dodgeball  game,  and  we  can't
dodge.  So,  our  only  hope  is  to  identify
asteroids  long  enough  in  advance  to  do
something  about  it.  We're  the  only
species  to  ever  have  a  hope  of  doing
that  for  anyone  else  when  an  asteroid
comes.
The  asteroid  that  killed  the  dinosaurs
was  wider  than  Mount  Everest  is  tall.
But  what  I  didn't  realize  is  that
asteroid,  it  wasn't  that  big.  At least
not  compared  to  other  asteroids  that
have  actually  hit  Earth  before.  Imagine
hunks  of  rock  or  metal,  all  different
shapes,  up  to  about  the  size  of  a
10-story  building.  There  are  likely
millions  of  these  flying  around  closer
to  us  than  Mars,  and  they  hit  us  all  the
time.  But  our  atmosphere  protects  us.
These  small  asteroids  almost  always  burn
up  long  before  they  reach  us  on  the
ground.  But  asteroids  get  bigger.  From
the  size  of  a  building  to  about  two  city
blocks,  there  are  likely  hundreds  of
thousands  of  asteroids  this  size  near
us.  On  June  30th,  1908,  a  rock  50  meters
across  grazed  our  atmosphere  over
Siberia.  It  never  even  hit  the  ground,
but  just  the  shock  wave  flattened  80
million  trees.  And  if  it  had  hit,  well,
an  asteroid  impact  is  worse  than  you
might  think.  Most  people  imagine  an
asteroid  hitting  Earth  like  a  bullet
hitting  a  wall.
But  an  asteroid  is  not  like  that.  An
asteroid  is  almost  always  going  so  fast
that  when  it  hits,  much  of  it
immediately  turns  from  a  solid  into  a
superheated  gas  that  explodes  outward.
And  the  energy  of  that  explosion  is
insane.  A  50  m  asteroid  would  release
the  energy  equivalent  of  around  500
nuclear  bombs.  That's  why  this  size  is
called  a  city  killer.  But  they  get
bigger.  Anything  this  size  would  wipe
out  a  whole  country.  And  anything  bigger
than  that,  all  life  on  Earth  would
change  forever.  That  rock  that  hit  the
dinosaurs  caused  mega  tsunamis,  a
thermal  pulse  of  heat  and  fire,  dust  and
ash  that  blocked  out  the  sun  for  a
decade  or  more.  But  that's  nowhere  close
to  the  largest  rock  that  has  ever  hit
Earth.  1.8  billion  years  ago,  a  rock
nearly  15  km  wide  slammed  into  what's
now  Canada.  And  170  million  years  before
that,  the  largest  asteroid  that  we  have
evidence  of  ever  hitting  Earth,  20
kilometers  wide,  struck  what  is  now
South  Africa.  If  you'd  been  on  the
ground  and  looked  up,  an  asteroid  that
size  would  look  something  like  this.  And
even  bigger  than  that,  it's  theorized
that  an  object  the  size  of  Mars  hit
Earth  about  4.5  billion  years  ago.  And
that's  how  our  moon  was  formed.  But
something  I  found  interesting  when
talking  to  experts  about  this  is  that
not  all  asteroids  hit  our  planet  the
same.  An  asteroid  made  of  ice  and  rocky
debris  might  hit  our  atmosphere  and
break  apart,  burning  up  on  entry,  while
a  dense  metal  asteroid  of  the  same  size
could  pierce  straight  through  and  maybe
do  more  serious  damage.  But  the  good
news  is  that  based  on  our  rate  of
discovery  and  computer  models  of  our
early  solar  system,  astronomers  say  that
we've  already  found  about  95  to  98%  of
the  really  big  asteroids,  the  ones  about
a  kilometer  wide  or  more.  As  of  today,
there  are  exactly  877  of  them.  And
scientists  track  them  very  closely.  And
luckily,  none  of  them  are  on  track  to
hit  us.  But  those  city  and  country
killers,  for  the  country  killers,  they
think  we've  only  found  42  to  47%  of
them.  And  for  the  city  killers,  the
number  is  much,  much  less.  And  we're
much  less  certain  about  that  percentage.
That  is  the  biggest  hole  in  Earth's
defenses  right  now.  And  that  is  what
people  all  around  the  world  are  staying
up  all  night  trying  to  fix.  And  I'm
about  to  become  one  of  them.

>> So,  what's  the  real  plan?  If  an  asteroid
that  big  actually  were  coming  for  Earth,
what  do  we  do?  Well,  in  2013,  the  United

That  doesn't  seem  like  a  great  plan,  but
there  is  still  a  chance  that  it  misses
us.  Option  two,  you  smash  a  spacecraft

just  enough  so  that  it  misses  Earth.
That  might  sound  like  science  fiction,

worked.

DART  was  small,  but  there  are  already
